timeline.message: abstract FixedSizeCache to allow interchangeability with ConcurrentHashMap

timeline.bodyText: I think naming this as capacity is a bit misleading...
timeline.author: tylerbenson

replies.bodyText: Well, what is it then? It's the capacity of the map's table immediately after construction, and unless there is irresponsible/unjustified usage and the map needs to be resized, it will remain the capacity of the map's table.
replies.author: richardstartin

replies.bodyText: Simply calling it capacity suggests there is a limit.  I'd suggest either Brian's proposal or expectedSize.
replies.author: tylerbenson

replies.bodyText: Calling it capacity suggests it has a capacity, but I think Brian's suggestion is a good one.
replies.author: richardstartin

replies.bodyText: I changed the name and added javadoc to the factory methods.
replies.author: richardstartin

timeline.bodyText: Why unbounded?  Seems a bit scary.
timeline.author: tylerbenson

replies.bodyText: I think there are implicit bounds in many cases, like the methods on a class. In those cases I think it's fine not to enforce a bound.
replies.author: richardstartin

replies.bodyText: I agree with that it's fine with unbounded here since there is a natural bound. Would be nice with a comment about the reasoning, i.e. that QualifiedClassNameCache is per Class and the number of methods are bounded.
replies.author: bantonsson

timeline.message: change capacity to initialCapacity, clarifying javadoc

timeline.author: bantonsson
